lines.text: Carlos Liston, a resident mad man and cleanup hitter.
I have to pitch to him today?
Yeah.
[laughs]
Just remember one thing, Carlos is a bit like a mad dog.
Mad dog?
If he smells fear, he goes into attack mode.
So, whatever you do,
Don't let him know that you are scared.
I need to use the bathroom.
Use the mound.
Skip, can I talk to you?
Sure, whats up Doc?
And here's Cerrano, returning to baseball after taking some time off to search for... whatever the hell it was he lost. Maybe his mind!
God... if You can hear me, *please*... send me *one* real baseball player. That's all I ask. And if you can't grant me that then... well... you might as well just strike me dead right here and now.
[he gets hit with the baseball]

Yes, sir, I remember Gus Cantrell from the old California AA League. That was before Diet Coke became my beverage of choice. Gus was a pretty fair pitcher, but he'll have to be more than "pretty fair" to bring this bunch close to anything resembling a baseball team.
[turns to color man and places his hand on the mic]
They suck.
Wingate is what you'd call a finesse pitcher. Relies on control, accuracy, not speed. They time this kid's fastball with an hourglass!
Hey Rube.
Hey Skip.
Say Rube, I was wondering, do you have any hidden skills?
Hidden skills?
Yeah, like if my car wasn't running right, would you be able to take the carburetor apart and fix it?
No. I don't know anything about carburetors.
How about if I bought some lumber, would you be able to build me a coffee table?
I don't think so.
So your skills have primarily lend themselves to baseball. Can we say that?
Yeah, we can say that.

If another routine ground ball lands 15 rows in the grandstands, I'm sending your ass home. So I suggest you make your throws. Or, I suggest you invest in some how-to books and find a fallback profession, understood.
Yeah.
[Rube leaves the dugout, and comes back in, and leaves again]
Mitt.
I thought you were going to give him the gentle speech.
That was it.
Perplexed? Carlton Windgate, pitcher. Everybody calls me Doc.
Gus Cantrell, manage. Everybody calls me Gus.
Nice to meet you. So do you have a question about the lineup?
Well, there seems to be a mistake. You have Juan Lopez playing second and Juan Lopez playing short.
Oh, that's no mistake. Juan?
Hola, Coach.
Buenos dias.
Brothers?
Twins. Confounding, isn't it?
Confounding seems to be the word of the day. Listen, from now on you'll be Juan 1.
Si.
And you'll be Juan 2.
Sounds good, coach.
By numbering them, you're identifying them and squelching their self esteem.
I don't mean to be rude Doc, but how would you like to be Juan 3?
Tell that son of a bitch to throw me his fastball.
That was his fastball.
The brothers Lopez steal second and third. Either somebody got their signals crossed or this is starting to look like a baseball team.
Gus Cantrell, you remember me?
Rube Baker, what are you doing here? I thought you were with San Diego.
I was with San Diego, but some throwing problems came back to haunt me.
Having trouble making the throw to second?
Yeah, second. And uh, first. Third, a little. I still have trouble getting the ball back to the pitcher.
Oh, come on I don't believe that. Just take it back and let 'er rip.
[Rube throws the ball, it leaves the field and hits a car]
Mom, they did it again.
So Pops, I was wondering, did you ever make it to the show?
Came close, once. It was with the Red Sox organization.
Yeah?
the weather is fine, so is the player.
That stinks.
20 years in the minors, I circled the show, couldn't land.
This is the clubhouse.
In some places of the world, this is called a basement.
It's cool in August. Other times, it can get musty.
Dank?
That too. There's your office.
Another prayer unanswered.
[Gus hears heavy breathing]
Lance Pere, this is Gus Cantrell, our new skipper.
Welcome to our unique little troop.
Thanks, you're not stuck or anything, are you?
No, it's yoga. As we go, so goes the world. For we are the world.
I'll have to jot that down.
You better unwind and get dressed unless you're planning on playing naked.
Will do, Pops.
He came here by way of New York City ballet.
Ballet?
He was such a natural athlete, they signed him.
He used to be a ballerina?
I don't think guys are ballerinas.
Balladeer?
Don't balladeers sing?
No, I think that's a troubadour.
Lance the Dance scores on what appears to be a triple axle thrown in with a salchow.
What's he doing, is that a curtsey?
Lance the Dance is entertaining the crowd. He is blowing kisses and curtseying. This must go back to his days as a balladeer.
Oh, he was a singer?
Dancer.
Oh.
Hog, he's crowding the plate, forcing you to throw to his power.
Might want to give him a little chin music.
You want me to throw at Carlos Liston?
He'll hate you tonight, but he'll respect him in the morning.
What do I do if he comes out here?
Climbing the center field wall wouldn't be a bad idea.
So, what's the deal with Carlos?
Well, Carlos is in a love fest, with Carlos.
What about the rest of your team.

One guy wants to be traded to New York so he can get more press coverage. My center fielder is threatening to quit because he wants to become a male model. And my second baseman and shortstop aren't speaking to each other because one has a bigger shoe contract than the other and they haven't turned a double play in over a month.
So out of your 25 guys, baseball is a primary concern for how many?
14. Maybe.
Gentlemen, some of you might want to check your contracts. You all set there, Rube?
Oh, yeah.

Yeah, just a little more mayo there. It seems that you guys signed on to play an entire season, but quit playing about 2/3 of the way through, and I want to know what the hell is going on. Anyone? Yeah, Hog.
Well, nobody thinks that we can win without Downtown.

Look, this game is not about one player. Believe me, I miss Downtown just as much as the rest of you. But baseball is about a team, an entire team, playing together. Yeah, look at me like I'm some damn corndog old man who doesn't know what the hell I'm talking about!

I don't know about the rest of you, but I remember not too long ago, we were the joke of the league. Now we've won some games. We even went dead even with the big team, and this man made the difference. I think we should listen to what he has to say.

Look, I'm not asking for too much. Just help the guy sitting next to you. Maybe you know something he doesn't. Maybe you can pass that information along. We're traveling tonight. We got the Crawdads tomorrow. By the time we hit the field, I expect everyone's minds to be on teamwork and the business of baseball. That cool?
Yeah, it's cool
All right, let's pack up and get out of here.
I'll tell you what, Rube. Playing a big league team, big league park, made the whole 20 years worthwhile.
It's a beautiful thing.
Do my eyes deceive me? Is that who I think it is?

[not turning around]
Slick guy, overdressed, helmet hair, shit-eating grin?

[turning around]
You must have eyes in the back of your head.
Leonard Huff, manager-slash-bullshit artist extraordinaire.

[seeing a newspaper article about the Buzz/Twins game]
Are you out of your mind?
You know, you are the fifth person this morning to ask me that question.
You bring Downtown up too early, you might have to send him back down, and that could really hurt the kid.
[Gus Cantrell is gaining consciousness after being knocked out with the ball]
God?
No.
Moses?
No, but you're getting warm.
Cerrano.

[chuckles]
Hello, Gus.

[laughs, then grabs the back of his head in pain]
Oh, Jesus Christ.
Be careful, now.
You scared me to death!
Do you mean when you realized God is black?
Yeah... I thought She was white.
[laughs]
I must've been out a long time if it's Halloween already.
What's your point?

Hold it right there! This here is a hundred mile hour fast ball. One of the best pitches known to man today. If it were to hit you, it would've knocked your head clean off. I can always miss, but I've been playing pretty good today, so you gotta ask yourself one question.
Do I feel lucky?
Well, do you Carlos?
Thou shalt not make fun of Carlos Liston or thou will get their asses whipped.
Family bicker. Customers complain. Everyone blames Taka. Have no... peace of brain.

[looks ahead after reading the newspaper on the bus]
Oh, my... Cerrano?
Yo?
Cerrano!

[approaches Gus]
Si, Gus, what?

[points at sign ahead]
Is that who I think it is?

[the sign is for Taka's Putt-Putt]
Jesus Christo. Tanaka!
[after accidentally-on-purpose spilling a soft drink on the Minnesota announcer]
Oh, I'm so sorry. Here, here's a twenty. Go get yourself another suit.
Pops, I got something for you.
[hands Pops a package]

[opens package]
This is a first baseman's glove.
That's funny, that's what the guy in the sporting goods store said it was.
I'm not a first baseman. I'm an outfielder. I been an outfielder my whole life.
Look, Pops, I think it might be better for the team...
Wait. Hold on, now. I've been around a long time. Don't give me the best for the team speech. Give it to me straight.
You're too old, you're too fat, you're too slow. Straight enough?
Yeah, yeah, that'll do it.
But I like your bat and I need a leader on the field and I think you're my man. What do you say? You wanna give first base a try?
Well, you know, whatever's best for the team.
So are you a baseball fan?
As a matter of fact, I am.
Well, I manage a team. Minnesota Twins, may you've heard of them.
Hmm, Minnesota Twins, may I've heard of them. You asshole.

[to himself, hearing the crowd chanting "Taka, Taka]
Something about Mt. Fuji... we think.
Did you know that Huff has "Born to Lie" tattooed on his forearm?
Is that the truth?
Skip, I talked to Rube, and I've discovered that Rube's entire throwing problem comes from a rather abrasive Little League Coach.
Rube can't throw for shit because of some jerk-off Little League coach?
In layman's terms, yes.
You, uh, you want me to go with the off-speed stuff?
You got anything else?
Nope.
I'd say we go with the off-speed stuff, then.
It's been a while.
Yeah, well one thing never changes.
What's that?
Butterflies.
Oh. What a decade to quit drinking.
[Rube throws a ground ball over the first base dugout and nearly hits Mr. Buzz]
Get some glasses, catcher!
[Mr. Buzz flips off Rube]
Wait a sec, Gus Cantrell, 6'1", 185 pounds, throws right, bats right.
Yeah.
Yeah, I had triples of your rookie card when I was in grade school.
Do you still have them?
No, I traded them all for one player to be named at a later date. I'm kidding.
Do you have nicoise?
I told you. We have ranch, Italian, and chunky bleu cheese, which is 50 cents extra.
Do you have any balsamic vinegar?
I got ranch, Italian, chunky bleu cheese.
How about a gun so I can shoot myself in the head?
That's it, it's over. I'm not a Pirate, I'm not a Yankee, I'm not even a Red Sock. I am a damn Buzz.
[a player spits in Huff's direction]
Thank you. Bumblebee, yeah, that's what I am, a Buzz.
One minute, you're talking about the new, improved, responsible, Gus Cantrell. The next, you are rolling across a bar room floor, kicking, punching, and biting.
I didn't bite him. Besides, it wasn't my fault.
How was it not your fault?
He asked he to hit him.
That's funny. I don't remember hearing him request a punch in the nose.
It's like a secret guy language. When someone pokes you with their finger more than once, they are saying, "Come on and hit me."
A secret guy language. Now, I know about the handshake, and the decoder ring, but this is new to me.

I hate to have to do this, but there's a speech clause in my contract. I know you guys have been reading the papers. That this is just a thing for publicity, part of my ongoing feud with Leonard Huff. But it would selfish of me to put you guys in such a jam just for publicity. No my motivation is deeper than that. It's ego.
[the players laugh]

I know your coaches would go out there to have fun or to fulfill your dream. I am asking that you win this one for me. Yeah! Win this one for Gus Cantrell! So let's stay loose, have fun, and let's go out there and take a bite out of the big team's ass!
As far as I'm concerned, as deal's a deal. I know how long you've been waiting to get to the Majors, plus I know that it has been a lifelong dream.

[Dorn presents Gus with a Twins hat]
Wow, I can't believe I'm saying this, but I think I'm going to have to pass.
I'm talking about a job with the Twins here, Gus.
I have a lot of information I feel I can pass on to young ballplayers. That's where I belong, and that's what I want to do.
You want to manage a minor league team?
So I'm going to stick with the Buzz, if that's okay with you.

[speechless]
Yeah it's okay, but...
But thanks.
Your attention please. Flight 63 to Miami is boarding at Gate 28.
Oh that's us.
Wait, where are you guys going?
It's called a honeymoon.
That's great. Congratulations! Hey, I don't have any plans. You mind if I come along.
Yeah, we do.
Gentleman, you know the ground rules. So shake hands and let's have a good, clean ballgame.
[Huff puts out his hand, Gus reluctantly shakes it. He tries to walk away, but Huff won't let him]
I'm going to give you the beating of your life.
We'll see about that.
Yeah we will.
Oh, by the way, some of the guys are wondering where you got your toupee.
This is not a toupee. This is real.
You can level with me, huh Lenny? Where'd you get it?

[Pulling on his hair]
It's real. It's mine.
Really?

[Still pulling on his hair]
It is and it's mine. You see this? Haha. Dumbass.

[Chuckling as he walks back to his dugout]
I'll, uh, tell the guys they were wrong.
[Huff realizes what he did and why the fans are laughing at him]

[after the Buzz make a comeback]
So much for beating them into submission.
Shut up!
[Huff hurls the baseball he's holding against the wall; it rebounds and knocks him out]
Get the trainer.
Gentlemen, this is NOT a "should win" or "want to win" situation.
play a big league team in a big league park.
This is a MUST WIN SITUATION!
No force, no push.

[yelling each word individually]
BEAT THEM INTO SUBMISSION!
Just relax. Let's have some fun.
Let's go! Let's go! I need some more runs now!
